title: Classic Oatmeal with Berries
instructions: Bring water to boil, add oats and reduce heat. Simmer for 5 minutes stirring occasionally. Top with berries, honey, and cinnamon.

detailed_instructions.description: Measure out 1 cup of rolled oats and 2 cups of water. Rinse fresh blueberries.
detailed_instructions.tip: Use old-fashioned rolled oats for best texture, not instant oats

detailed_instructions.description: Pour 2 cups of water into a medium saucepan and bring to a rolling boil over high heat.
detailed_instructions.tip: Adding a pinch of salt enhances the flavor

detailed_instructions.description: Once water is boiling, add the oats and stir well. Reduce heat to medium-low.
detailed_instructions.tip: Stir immediately to prevent clumping

detailed_instructions.description: Let the oats simmer gently, stirring occasionally, until they absorb the water and reach desired consistency.
detailed_instructions.tip: For creamier oats, add more water and cook longer

detailed_instructions.description: Transfer oatmeal to bowl. Top with fresh blueberries, drizzle with honey, and sprinkle with cinnamon.
detailed_instructions.tip: Let oatmeal cool for 1-2 minutes before adding honey to preserve its beneficial enzymes

rolled_oats.nutrients: Rich in manganese, phosphorus, magnesium, iron, and B vitamins
rolled_oats.why_good: Whole grain that keeps you full longer and supports heart health

blueberries.nutrients: High in vitamin C, vitamin K, and manganese
blueberries.why_good: One of the most antioxidant-rich foods, protects cells from damage

honey.nutrients: Contains trace amounts of vitamins and minerals
honey.why_good: Provides quick energy with some beneficial compounds, unlike white sugar

cinnamon.nutrients: Good source of manganese and calcium
cinnamon.why_good: Helps control blood sugar spikes after meals

what_to_avoid: Instant oats with added sugar - they spike blood sugar
Artificial sweeteners - use natural honey instead
Excessive honey - stick to 1 tbsp to control sugar intake
Microwaving in plastic containers - use glass or ceramic

health_notes.timing: Ideal for breakfast - provides sustained energy for 3-4 hours

modifications.higher_protein: Add 1 scoop protein powder or 2 tbsp nut butter
modifications.lower_carb: Use 1/2 cup oats and add more nuts/seeds
modifications.vegan: Already vegan! Replace honey with maple syrup if needed

title: Scrambled Eggs with Toast
instructions: Beat eggs with salt and pepper. Melt butter in pan, add eggs and scramble until cooked. Toast bread and serve together.

detailed_instructions.description: Crack 3 eggs into a bowl. Add a pinch of salt and pepper. Whisk vigorously with a fork until yolks and whites are fully combined and slightly frothy.
detailed_instructions.tip: Whisking air into eggs makes them fluffier

detailed_instructions.description: Place a non-stick pan over medium-low heat. Add 1 tbsp butter and let it melt completely, swirling to coat the pan.
detailed_instructions.tip: Medium-low heat is key - high heat makes eggs rubbery

detailed_instructions.description: Pour beaten eggs into the pan. Let sit for 20 seconds, then gently push eggs from edges to center with a spatula. Continue until eggs are mostly set but still slightly wet.
detailed_instructions.tip: Remove from heat when eggs are still slightly wet - they'll continue cooking

detailed_instructions.description: While eggs cook, toast whole wheat bread slices until golden brown.
detailed_instructions.tip: Toast bread at the same time as cooking eggs to serve everything hot

detailed_instructions.description: Transfer scrambled eggs to plate immediately. Serve with toasted bread.
detailed_instructions.tip: Serve immediately for best texture and temperature

benefits: Rich in choline for brain health
eggs.nutrients: High in protein, vitamin B12, vitamin D, selenium, and healthy fats
eggs.why_good: One of the most nutritious foods - the yolk contains most vitamins and minerals

whole_wheat_bread.nutrients: Good source of fiber, iron, magnesium, and B vitamins
whole_wheat_bread.why_good: Whole grains provide sustained energy and keep you full longer

butter.nutrients: Rich in vitamin A, vitamin E, and vitamin K2
butter.why_good: Natural fat that helps absorb fat-soluble vitamins from eggs

what_to_avoid: Overcooking eggs - makes them dry and rubbery
High heat - causes eggs to become tough
White bread - lacks fiber and nutrients
Margarine - contains trans fats, use real butter
Adding milk - makes eggs watery (optional, but not recommended)

health_notes.timing: Perfect breakfast - high protein keeps you full until lunch

modifications.higher_protein: Add 1-2 more eggs or serve with turkey sausage
modifications.lower_fat: Use 2 whole eggs + 2 egg whites, reduce butter to 1 tsp
modifications.add_veggies: Mix in spinach, tomatoes, or mushrooms for extra nutrients

title: Grilled Chicken Salad
instructions: Grill chicken breast and slice. Toss greens, tomatoes, and cucumber. Top with chicken and drizzle with oil and vinegar.

detailed_instructions.description: Pat chicken breast dry with paper towels. Season both sides with salt, pepper, and optional herbs (garlic powder, paprika).
detailed_instructions.tip: Dry chicken browns better and gets nice grill marks

detailed_instructions.description: Preheat grill or grill pan to medium-high heat. Brush with oil. Grill chicken for 6-7 minutes per side until internal temperature reaches 165°F (74°C).
detailed_instructions.tip: Don't flip too early - let it develop grill marks first

detailed_instructions.description: Remove chicken from grill and let rest for 5 minutes before slicing. This keeps it juicy.
detailed_instructions.tip: Resting allows juices to redistribute throughout the meat

detailed_instructions.description: While chicken rests, wash and dry mixed greens. Halve cherry tomatoes. Slice cucumber into thin rounds.
detailed_instructions.tip: Dry greens well so dressing adheres properly

detailed_instructions.description: In a small bowl, whisk together olive oil and balsamic vinegar. Add a pinch of salt and pepper.
detailed_instructions.tip: Ratio is 2:1 oil to vinegar for balanced flavor

detailed_instructions.description: Place greens in a large bowl. Add tomatoes and cucumber. Slice chicken and arrange on top. Drizzle with dressing.
detailed_instructions.tip: Dress salad just before eating to keep greens crisp

chicken_breast.nutrients: High in protein, niacin, vitamin B6, phosphorus, and selenium
chicken_breast.why_good: One of the leanest protein sources - perfect for muscle building and weight loss

benefits: High in vitamins A, C, K
mixed_greens.nutrients: Excellent source of folate, iron, calcium, and fiber
mixed_greens.why_good: Nutrient-dense with minimal calories - great for weight management

cherry_tomatoes.nutrients: High in vitamin C, potassium, and vitamin K
cherry_tomatoes.why_good: Lycopene is more bioavailable when tomatoes are cooked or paired with fat (olive oil)

cucumber.nutrients: Good source of vitamin K and potassium
cucumber.why_good: Adds crunch and hydration with almost no calories

olive_oil.nutrients: High in vitamin E and polyphenols
olive_oil.why_good: One of the healthiest fats - cornerstone of Mediterranean diet

balsamic_vinegar.nutrients: Contains small amounts of calcium, iron, and potassium
balsamic_vinegar.why_good: Adds tangy flavor with minimal calories and some health benefits

what_to_avoid: Overcooking chicken - makes it dry (use meat thermometer)
Store-bought dressings - often high in sugar and preservatives
Iceberg lettuce - has minimal nutrients compared to mixed greens
Too much dressing - drowns the salad and adds excess calories
Grilling on too high heat - burns outside while inside stays raw

health_notes.timing: Perfect for lunch - high protein keeps you satisfied without afternoon crash

modifications.higher_carbs: Add quinoa, chickpeas, or sweet potato
modifications.different_protein: Substitute with salmon, tofu, or shrimp
modifications.meal_prep: Grill multiple chicken breasts and store for 3-4 days

title: Quinoa Buddha Bowl
instructions: Cook quinoa according to package. Roast vegetables at 400F for 20 minutes. Assemble bowl with quinoa, chickpeas, and vegetables. Drizzle with tahini-lemon dressing.

detailed_instructions.description: Rinse 1/2 cup dry quinoa under cold water. Combine with 1 cup water in a pot. Bring to boil, reduce heat, cover and simmer for 15 minutes. Fluff with fork.
detailed_instructions.tip: Rinsing quinoa removes bitter coating called saponin

detailed_instructions.description: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Chop vegetables (bell peppers, zucchini, broccoli) into bite-sized pieces. Toss with 1 tbsp olive oil, salt, and pepper.
detailed_instructions.tip: Cut vegetables similar size for even roasting

detailed_instructions.description: Spread vegetables on baking sheet in single layer. Roast for 20-25 minutes, stirring halfway, until tender and slightly caramelized.
detailed_instructions.tip: Don't overcrowd the pan or vegetables will steam instead of roast

detailed_instructions.description: If using canned, drain and rinse chickpeas. Pat dry and optionally roast with vegetables for extra crunch.
detailed_instructions.tip: Roasted chickpeas add great texture and flavor

detailed_instructions.description: Whisk together 2 tbsp tahini, 1 tbsp lemon juice, 1 tbsp water, and a pinch of salt until smooth and creamy.
detailed_instructions.tip: Add water gradually to reach desired consistency

detailed_instructions.description: Place quinoa in bowl as base. Arrange roasted vegetables and chickpeas on top. Drizzle with tahini dressing. Optional: add avocado, seeds, or fresh herbs.
detailed_instructions.tip: Arrange ingredients in sections for beautiful presentation

quinoa.nutrients: Excellent source of manganese, magnesium, phosphorus, folate, and iron
quinoa.why_good: One of few plant foods with complete protein - perfect for vegetarians

chickpeas.nutrients: Good source of protein, fiber, folate, iron, and phosphorus
chickpeas.why_good: Filling and nutritious - keeps you satisfied for hours

roasted_vegetables.nutrients: Varies by vegetable - generally high in vitamins A, C, K, and fiber
roasted_vegetables.why_good: Roasting concentrates flavors and makes vegetables more appealing

tahini.nutrients: High in calcium, magnesium, iron, and B vitamins
tahini.why_good: Made from sesame seeds - provides healthy fats and minerals

lemon_juice.nutrients: Excellent source of vitamin C and antioxidants
lemon_juice.why_good: Helps absorb iron from plant foods like quinoa and chickpeas

what_to_avoid: Not rinsing quinoa - leaves bitter taste
Overcooking quinoa - makes it mushy
Overcrowding vegetables on pan - they'll steam not roast
Using old tahini - can taste rancid
Skipping lemon juice - it brightens all the flavors

health_notes.timing: Perfect for lunch - provides sustained energy without afternoon slump

modifications.higher_protein: Add tofu, tempeh, or extra chickpeas
modifications.lower_carb: Replace half the quinoa with cauliflower rice
modifications.nut_free: Replace tahini with sunflower seed butter
modifications.meal_prep: Make large batch - stores well for 4-5 days

title: Baked Salmon with Vegetables
instructions: Preheat oven to 400F. Season salmon and vegetables with oil and spices. Bake for 15-18 minutes until salmon is cooked through. Serve with lemon.

detailed_instructions.description: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or lightly oil it.
detailed_instructions.tip: Parchment paper makes cleanup easier and prevents sticking

detailed_instructions.description: Pat salmon fillet dry with paper towels. Check for pin bones and remove with tweezers. Season both sides with salt, pepper, and herbs (dill, thyme, or garlic powder).
detailed_instructions.tip: Dry salmon ensures crispy skin and better seasoning adhesion

detailed_instructions.description: Cut vegetables (asparagus, broccoli, bell peppers) into similar-sized pieces. Toss with olive oil, salt, and pepper.
detailed_instructions.tip: Choose vegetables with similar cooking times

detailed_instructions.description: Place salmon skin-side down in center of baking sheet. Arrange vegetables around salmon in single layer.
detailed_instructions.tip: Give vegetables space so they roast instead of steam

detailed_instructions.description: Bake for 12-15 minutes for 1-inch thick salmon, or until internal temperature reaches 145°F (63°C). Salmon should flake easily with fork.
detailed_instructions.tip: Don't overcook - salmon continues cooking after removing from oven

detailed_instructions.description: Transfer salmon and vegetables to plate. Squeeze fresh lemon juice over everything. Garnish with fresh herbs if desired.
detailed_instructions.tip: Lemon juice enhances flavor and helps absorb omega-3s

salmon.nutrients: Excellent source of omega-3s, vitamin D, vitamin B12, selenium, and protein
salmon.why_good: One of the best sources of omega-3 fatty acids - essential for heart and brain health

mixed_vegetables.nutrients: Varies by vegetable - generally high in vitamins A, C, K, and folate
mixed_vegetables.why_good: Variety of vegetables provides diverse nutrients and phytochemicals

olive_oil.nutrients: High in vitamin E and polyphenols
olive_oil.why_good: Helps absorb fat-soluble vitamins from vegetables

lemon.nutrients: Excellent source of vitamin C and flavonoids
lemon.why_good: Vitamin C helps absorb iron and enhances omega-3 absorption

what_to_avoid: Overcooking salmon - makes it dry (aim for 145°F internal temp)
Farmed salmon with added color - choose wild-caught when possible
Cooking at too high temperature - can burn outside while inside stays raw
Not removing pin bones - unpleasant to eat
Skipping the lemon - it's essential for flavor and nutrient absorption

health_notes.timing: Perfect for dinner - omega-3s may improve sleep quality

modifications.budget_friendly: Use frozen salmon or substitute with mackerel
modifications.more_filling: Serve with quinoa or sweet potato
modifications.meal_prep: Bake multiple fillets - stores for 2-3 days

title: Vegetarian Stir-Fry
instructions: Cook rice according to package. Press and cube tofu. Stir-fry tofu until golden, add vegetables and cook until tender. Add soy sauce and sesame oil. Serve over rice.

detailed_instructions.description: Rinse 1/2 cup brown rice. Combine with 1 cup water in pot. Bring to boil, reduce heat, cover and simmer for 40-45 minutes. Let stand 5 minutes, then fluff.
detailed_instructions.tip: Start rice first as it takes longest - or use pre-cooked rice to save time

detailed_instructions.description: Drain tofu and wrap in clean kitchen towel. Place heavy object on top (like a cast iron pan) and press for 15-20 minutes to remove excess water.
detailed_instructions.tip: Pressing tofu makes it crispier and helps it absorb flavors better

detailed_instructions.description: Cut pressed tofu into 3/4-inch cubes. Chop vegetables (bell peppers, broccoli, snap peas, carrots) into bite-sized pieces.
detailed_instructions.tip: Cut vegetables similar size for even cooking

detailed_instructions.description: Heat 1 tbsp oil in large wok or skillet over medium-high heat. Add tofu cubes in single layer. Cook 3-4 minutes per side until golden and crispy. Remove and set aside.
detailed_instructions.tip: Don't move tofu too much - let it develop a golden crust

detailed_instructions.description: Add vegetables to same pan. Stir-fry for 5-7 minutes until tender-crisp. Add harder vegetables (carrots, broccoli) first, softer ones (peppers, snap peas) later.
detailed_instructions.tip: Keep vegetables moving for even cooking and to prevent burning

detailed_instructions.description: Return tofu to pan. Add soy sauce and sesame oil. Toss everything together for 1-2 minutes. Serve immediately over brown rice.
detailed_instructions.tip: Add sauce at the end to prevent burning and maintain crispy tofu

tofu.nutrients: Good source of protein, iron, calcium, magnesium, and isoflavones
tofu.why_good: Versatile plant protein that absorbs flavors well - great meat alternative

mixed_vegetables.nutrients: Varies by vegetable - generally high in vitamins A, C, K, and fiber
mixed_vegetables.why_good: Variety provides diverse nutrients and makes meal more satisfying

soy_sauce.nutrients: Contains small amounts of protein and minerals
soy_sauce.why_good: Adds depth of flavor with minimal calories - use low-sodium version

sesame_oil.nutrients: Good source of vitamin E and omega-6 fatty acids
sesame_oil.why_good: Small amount adds big flavor - use as finishing oil

brown_rice.nutrients: Good source of manganese, selenium, magnesium, and B vitamins
brown_rice.why_good: More nutritious than white rice - keeps you full longer

what_to_avoid: Not pressing tofu - results in soggy, bland tofu
Overcrowding the pan - tofu won't get crispy
Using silken tofu - too soft for stir-frying (use firm or extra-firm)
Too much soy sauce - can be overly salty
Overcooking vegetables - they should be tender-crisp, not mushy

health_notes.timing: Great for dinner - satisfying and nutritious

modifications.higher_protein: Use extra-firm tofu or add edamame
modifications.gluten_free: Use tamari instead of soy sauce
modifications.more_flavor: Add ginger, garlic, or chili flakes

title: Greek Yogurt with Nuts
instructions: Place yogurt in bowl, top with nuts and drizzle with honey.

detailed_instructions.description: Use plain, full-fat or 2% Greek yogurt. Avoid flavored varieties with added sugar.
detailed_instructions.tip: Full-fat yogurt is more satisfying and helps absorb fat-soluble vitamins

detailed_instructions.description: Measure 1/4 cup mixed nuts (almonds, walnuts, pecans). Optionally toast in dry pan for 2-3 minutes for enhanced flavor.
detailed_instructions.tip: Toasting nuts brings out their natural oils and makes them crunchier

detailed_instructions.description: Spoon Greek yogurt into bowl. Sprinkle nuts on top. Drizzle with honey in a decorative pattern.
detailed_instructions.tip: Layer ingredients for visual appeal and better flavor distribution

greek_yogurt.nutrients: Excellent source of protein, calcium, vitamin B12, and probiotics
greek_yogurt.why_good: Double the protein of regular yogurt - keeps you full and supports muscle

mixed_nuts.nutrients: Good source of vitamin E, magnesium, healthy fats, and fiber
mixed_nuts.why_good: Combination of protein, healthy fats, and fiber provides lasting satiety

honey.nutrients: Contains trace amounts of vitamins and minerals
honey.why_good: Provides sweetness with some beneficial compounds

what_to_avoid: Flavored yogurt - often contains as much sugar as ice cream
Low-fat or fat-free yogurt - less satisfying and may have added sugar
Salted or candied nuts - adds unnecessary sodium and sugar
Too much honey - stick to 1 tbsp to control sugar
Yogurt with artificial sweeteners - may disrupt gut bacteria

health_notes.timing: Perfect afternoon snack or post-workout - protein aids recovery

modifications.higher_protein: Add protein powder or extra nuts
modifications.lower_sugar: Skip honey or use cinnamon for sweetness
modifications.add_fruit: Top with berries for extra antioxidants

title: Apple with Almond Butter
instructions: Slice apple and serve with almond butter for dipping.

detailed_instructions.description: Select a crisp apple variety like Honeycrisp, Fuji, or Granny Smith. Wash thoroughly under running water.
detailed_instructions.tip: Different varieties offer different sweetness levels - Granny Smith is tart, Fuji is sweet

detailed_instructions.description: Cut apple into quarters, remove core, then slice each quarter into 3-4 wedges. Aim for 12-16 slices total.
detailed_instructions.tip: Squeeze lemon juice on slices to prevent browning if not eating immediately

detailed_instructions.description: Measure 2 tbsp almond butter into small bowl. If too thick, stir in a few drops of water to make it more dippable.
detailed_instructions.tip: Choose natural almond butter with no added sugar or oils

detailed_instructions.description: Arrange apple slices on plate with almond butter in center for dipping. Optional: sprinkle cinnamon on apple slices.
detailed_instructions.tip: Cinnamon adds flavor and may help regulate blood sugar

apple.nutrients: Good source of vitamin C, potassium, and fiber
apple.why_good: Fiber keeps you full and supports digestive health - eat with skin for maximum benefits

almond_butter.nutrients: Excellent source of vitamin E, magnesium, healthy fats, and protein
almond_butter.why_good: Combination of protein and healthy fats balances apple's natural sugars

what_to_avoid: Peeling the apple - most fiber and nutrients are in the skin
Almond butter with added sugar or palm oil - choose natural
Too much almond butter - stick to 2 tbsp (it's calorie-dense)
Eating apple alone - adding fat/protein prevents blood sugar spike
Browning apple slices - use lemon juice if preparing ahead

health_notes.timing: Perfect afternoon snack or pre-workout - provides quick and sustained energy

modifications.more_protein: Add a hard-boiled egg on the side
modifications.different_nut_butter: Try peanut, cashew, or sunflower seed butter
modifications.add_toppings: Sprinkle with chia seeds, hemp seeds, or cinnamon
